A series of Zn- and Co containing zeolitic-imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), such as ZIF-8(Zn)/ZIF-67(Co), MAF-5(Zn)/MAF-5(Co), and MAF-6(Zn)/MAF-6(Co), were investigated as catalysts for the synthesis of propylene carbonate (PC) from propylene oxide (PO) and CO2. The effect of the chemical composition, textural, structural and physicochemical properties on their activity was investigated. It was found that the activity of Zn-containing materials was higher in comparison with Co-based materials. Moreover, the yield of a PC was decreased with increasing Co content in structure of mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs (ZIF-8/ZIF-67) that was related to the accessibility of active centers to reagents and the strength of their interaction with CO2 and propylene oxide. The catalytic performance of Zn-ZIFs was found to improve with increasing the size of pore aperture due to the guest molecule facile diffusion and accessibility of the active site for reagent. In general, based on the results of the present work, the Zn-ZIFs could be considered as promising catalysts for cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides and thereby opens new paths for further research. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks Catalytic properties Propylene carbonate CO2 Propylene oxide Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) have attracted the interest of researchers for more than 20 years due to their unique structural, textural and physicochemical properties that can be varied in wide ranges by a combination of the nature of metal ions and organic ligand. Their structures are formed by an imidazole linker coordinated with a tetrahedral metal atom (Zn2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Cd2+ etc.). Structure and physicochemical properties of these materials have some very peculiar similarities with the conventional zeolites [1–4]. Thus, ZIFs possess high surface areas, unimodal micropores, high crystallinities, abundant functionalities and exceptional thermal and chemical stabilities [5,6] which renders ZIFs holding great promise in many applications including catalysis [7]. Note that the first ZIF, namely [Co5(IM)10·2MB]∞ formed by Со2+, imidazole (IM) and 3-methyl-1-butanol (MB), was synthesized in 2002 [8]. Since time, more than 200 ZIF-type structures have been reported. However, a limited number of materials like ZIF-8, ZIF-67, ZIF-90, MAF-5 (ZIF-14), and MAF-6 (ZIF-71) have been used in catalysis (Table 1 ). Significant information on the physicochemical and catalytic properties of these ZIFs has been obtained at the present time [10–14]. Probably, such situation is associated with the most detailed study of their physicochemical properties. Thus, it was demonstrated that the chemical composition of the linker can affect hydrophobic/hydrophilic properties of ZIFs [15]. ZIF-90 is a completely hydrophilic material due to the strong hydrophilic aldehyde group in the structure of the linker, while the ZIF-8, MAF-5, and MAF-6 are hydrophobic materials due to the –CH3 and –CH2CH3 groups on the linker. As a result, catalytic properties of ZIFs quite often outperform that of zeolites and zeolitic materials in the presence of polar compounds [16–18]. For example, it is well-known that beta zeolite is an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, however, in the cycloaddition of CO2 to epichlorohydrin at 70 °C beta zeolite was substantially inferior to ZIF-8 [18]. Note that TS-1, HY, and SBA-15 were still less active than ZIF-8 even at 80 °C. It is noteworthy that, like zeolites, the crystallite size of ZIFs can affect the rate and selectivity of the processes. This phenomenon was demonstrated for ZIF-8 in Knoevenagel reactions [19–21], Friedländer reaction [20], cascade processes, including the intermolecular variant of [3 + 3] cycloaddition [22], synthesis of 1-methoxy-2-propanol from propylene oxide and methanol [23], and synthesis of erythrulose from formaldehyde and dihydroxyacetone [24]. Recently, we found a similar effect for MAF-6 (ZIF-71) [12]. MAF-6 samples with particle size of 190 ± 20, 360 ± 30 and 810 ± 30 nm were used as catalysts for solvent-free coupling of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) (Scheme 1 ). This reaction allows producing the propylene carbonate (PC) which is widely used as lubricants, surface coatings, plasticizers, lithium battery electrolytes, solvents, selective reagents, fuel additives, monomers for polymers and intermediates in the production of pharmaceuticals and other fine chemicals [25–27]. Investigation of this reaction by us pointed that, the yield of a PC decreased with increasing crystal size of the MAF-6 material due to the change in textural properties, and the increasing number of active sites in surface of a solid. The maximal yield of a PC was 80.5% in the presence of binary system MAF-6(190 nm)/[n-Bu4N]Br at 80 °C for 5 h (Table 2 ). Note that yield of PC in the presence of binary system MAF-5(260 nm)/[n-Bu4N]Br was lower (66%) in comparison with MAF-6(190 nm)/[n-Bu4N]Br that, probably, can be explained by the difference in their structural and textural characteristics which affect the accessibility of active sites for the reagents and increasing diffusion limitations. In general, ZIFs were reported as efficient catalysts in the cycloaddition of CO2 to PO (Tables 2 and 3 ) [12,28–37]. The yield of a PC was 49–97% with 95–99% selectivity in the presence of ZIF-67, ZIF-23, ZIF-90, and ZIF-95 (Tables 2 and S1, Supporting Information (SI)) and their binary systems ZIF/[n-Bu4N]Br at 0.8–1.2 MPa of CO2 and 100–140 °C (Table 3). Unfortunately, despite the significant information on the physicochemical and catalytic properties of ZIFs, searching for the ZIF-based active catalytic systems, many researchers rely on an empirical method. Often, they are limited to consideration of the optimization of the reaction conditions of successful catalytic systems, while the reasons for the high activity of these systems are not always studied in detail. Thus, effect of Co content in framework of Co,Zn-ZIF on catalytic behavior is discrepant. According to Nguyen et al. [36], synthesized Co,Zn-ZIF (Co:Zn = 1:1) from 3 mmol of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 3 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 48.3 mmol of 2-MIM (2-MIM/(Co2++ Zn2+) – 8 mol/mol) in methanol. It was demonstrated that in cycloaddition of CO2 to epichlorohydrin (EP) conversion of EP in the presence of ZIF-8 was slightly lower (65.4%) in comparison with Co,Zn-ZIF (Co:Zn = 1:1) (69.4%). Selectivity towards cyclic carbonate was 98–99% in the presence of studied samples. At the same time, Kuruppathparambil et al. [34] synthesized Zn,Co-ZIF (1:1) from 0.78 mmol of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.78 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 67.1 mmol of 2-MIM (2-MIM/(Co2++ Zn2+) – 43.0 mol/mol) in aqueous solution (28 ml). It was demonstrated that activity of Co,Zn-ZIF also depended on the Co content in the framework of solid. However, Conversion of EP in the presence of ZIF-8 was higher (98.2%) in comparison with Co,Zn-ZIF (Co:Zn = 1:1) (94.8%). In general, conversion of EPH decreased in the order: ZIF-8 (98.2%) > Zn,Co-ZIF (2:1) (96%) > Zn,Co-ZIF (1:1) (94.8%) > Zn,Co-ZIF (1:2) (80.2%) > ZIF-67 (66.5%). Note that selectivity towards cyclic carbonate in the presence of ZIF-8 was lower (33.4%) than that of all Co,Zn-ZIF (90–98%). Therefore, it seemed necessary to investigate the possibility of tuning the catalytic properties of ZIFs in the cycloaddition of CO2 to propylene oxide by the variation of their structure and chemical composition. In this study, we will continue our studies of catalytic properties of ZIFs in order to establish the main factors that allow us to regulate their activity in cycloaddition of CO2 to PO. We synthesized and investigated Co-, Zn- and mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs, such as MAF-6(Zn)/MAF-6(Co), MAF-5(Zn)/MAF-5(Co), ZIF-8(Zn)/ZIF-67(Co) and mixed ZIF-8(Zn)/ZIF-67(Co) (Zn,Co-ZIFs, Zn:Co - 100:0, 75:25, 50:50 and 25:75 at./at.). The main attention was focused on revealing (a) the effect of the chemical composition, structure, texture on their catalytic properties, (b) the effect of the strength of basic sites on activity of Zn-ZIFs, and (c) assessing the potential of Co,Zn-ZIFs for further use in CO2 catalysis. We can assume that differences in chemical composition and structure of the studied ZIFs will allow us to both increase and control the reaction rate. We used a combination of catalytic and physicochemical methods to support such suggestion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Propylene oxide (> 98%), styrene oxide (99%), methanol, and n-tetrabutyl ammonium bromide ([n-Bu4N]Br) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Zn(NO3)·9H2O, Co(NO3)·6H2O, Co(OAc)2·4H2O (98%), 2-methylimidazole (2-MIM), 2-ethylimidazole (2-EIM), triethylamine (N(C2H5)3, 99.5%), benzene, and cyclohexane were purchased from Acros Organic. The obtained chemicals were used without further purification. ZIF-8, ZIF-67, and Zn,Co-ZIFs were synthesized according to the procedure described in Refs. [38,39]. Briefly, the methanol solutions of Zn(NO3)2, Co(NO3)2 or a mixture of both metal salts (total content of salts was 2.5 mmol) were added to the methanol solution of 2-MIM (20.2 mmol) (Table S2, SI). After complete addition, the solution was vigorously stirred for the next 1 h at 60 °C. Then, the formed precipitate was separated using a centrifuge (4500 rpm for 10 min) and washed three times with methanol. The obtained product was dried at room temperature under vacuum for 5 h. Chemical composition of Zn,Co-ZIFs are given in Table 4 . The main physicochemical and textural properties are shown in Table 5 and Figs. S1–S3 (SI). MAF-6(Zn) samples were synthesized from 2-EIM and [Zn(NH3)4](OH)2 according to the method described in Refs. [40,41]. Briefly, 4 mmol of 2-EIM was dissolved in a mixed solvent (propyl alcohol/cyclohexane 28.5 : 1.5 vol./vol.). 2 mmol of Zn(OH)2 was dissolved in 30 ml of aqueous NH3 (25%) solution. After addition of [Zn(NH3)4](OH)2 to the 2-EIM solution, the mixture was vigorously stirred for 20 min at room temperature. Then the formed precipitate was separated using a centrifuge (4500 rpm for 10 min), washed three times with methanol and was dried at room temperature under vacuum for 5 h. The main physicochemical and textural properties are shown in Table 5 and Figs. S4–S6 (SI). MAF-6(Co) was prepared from 2-EIM and Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O, according to Ref. [41]. Briefly, solution (1) was prepared by dissolving 2 mmol of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O in 50 mL of ethanol. Solution (2) was obtained by dissolving 16 mmol of 2-EIM in 50 mL of a solution (ethanol/cyclohexane 90/10 vol./vol. and 16 mmol of TEA). The solution (1) was added rapidly to the solution (2) and the resultant slurry was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The purple solid was collected by filtration and washed with ethanol and dried similar to the previous one. The main physicochemical and textural properties are shown in Table 5 and Figs. S5, S6 (SI). MAF-5(Zn) was synthesized from 2-EIM and [Zn(NH3)4](OH)2 according to the method described in Ref. [41]. Briefly, 2 mmol of Zn(OH)2 in 40 mL of a aqueous ammonia solution (25%) was added to 40 mL of a solution composed of methanol/cyclohexane 97/3 vol./vol. and 4 mmol of 2-EIM. The mixture was then stirred for 1 h at room temperature and the resultant crystals were separated followed by washing with methanol. The main physicochemical and textural properties are shown in Table 5 and Figs. S4–S6 (SI). MAF-5(Co) was synthesized from 2-EIM and Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O according to Ref. [41]. Briefly, solution (1) was prepared by dissolving 2 mmol of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O in 25 mL of water. Solution (2) was obtained by dissolving 16 mmol of 2-EIM in 50 mL of a solution (water/benzene 90/10 vol./vol. and 16 mmol of TEA). The solution (1) was added rapidly to the solution (2) and the resultant slurry was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The as-synthesized bright purple MAF-5(Co) crystals were initially kept inside the vacuum hood to evaporate the washing solvent and then dried at 100 °C in a vacuum for overnight. The main physicochemical and textural properties are shown in Table 5 and Figs. S5, S6 (SI). 2.2 Instrumental measurements Chemical analyses were done by an inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) using a PERKIN-ELMER instrument OPTIMA 4300. The textural characteristics of the MAF-5 and MAF-6 samples were determined from the adsorption isotherm of N2 at −196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2400. All samples were heat-treated at 150 °C under vacuum overnight before the analysis. Total pore volume was evaluated according to the Gurvich rule [42] from adsorption uptake under p/p° = 0.98 (corresponding to pores size of 100 nm and less), micropore volume was measured according to the Lippens-de Boer t-method [43], the specific surface area was measured by means of the MA modification of the BET method [44]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by using a Thermo ARL X'tra device, with the CuKα-radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), focusing geometry θ−2θ in the scanning mode within the range of angles of 2θ from 3 to 75° with the step of 0.05°. DRIFT spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu FTIR-8300S spectrometer with a DRS-8000 diffusion reflectance cell in the range between 400 and 6000 cm–1 with a resolution of 4 cm–1. All spectra are presented in F(R) Kubelka-Munk scale: F ( R ) = ( 1 − R ) 2 2 R , where R is reflection coefficient. The DR-UV-vis spectra were recorded on a UV-2501 PC Shimadzu spectrometer with an IRS-250A accessory in the 190–900 nm range with a resolution of 2 nm, on samples in powder form placed into a special cell for DR-UV-vis measurement. BaSO4 was used as a standard for measurements. 2.3 Catalytic tests The cycloaddition of propylene epoxide with CO2 was carried out in an autoclave with a magnetic stirrer (Tynyclave steel, Buchiglasuster, inner volume of 25 mL). The typical procedure was as follows: 50 mg of catalyst, 50 mg of co-catalyst ([n-Bu4N]Br) and 24 mmol of propylene oxide were added into the autoclave. Then CO2 (99.9%) was introduced into the autoclave, before this, the air was replaced with CO2 until reaching the appropriated pressure (0.8 MPa). The autoclave was then heated to an appropriate temperature (80 °C) for 5 h with continuous magnetic stirring (800 rpm). Note that the maximum pressure was 1.2 MPa at 80 °C, which decreased in the course of reaction. After the reaction completion, the autoclave was cooled in an ice-water bath and the remaining CO2 was vented. The product was extracted with toluene and the reaction mixture was analyzed with a GC (Agilent 7820) equipped with a flame ionization detector and HP-5 capillary column. As an internal standard, n-decane was used. The error of measurement was less than 10%. The typical procedure of the cycloaddition of styrene epoxide with CO2 was as follows: 50 mg of catalyst and 20 mmol of styrene oxide were added into the autoclave. Then CO2 (99.9%) was introduced into the autoclave, before this, the air was replaced with CO2 until reaching the appropriated pressure (1.2 MPa). The autoclave was then heated to an appropriate temperature (50 °C) for 24 h with continuous magnetic stirring (800 rpm). After the reaction completion, the recovery and analysis of products were done similar to the cycloaddition of CO2 to propylene oxide. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of ZIFs Synthesis and characterization of mixed ZIF-8/ZIF-67 materials. The mixed Co,Zn-ZIFs samples with different Zn/Co atomic ratio were synthesized in methanol at 60 °C via a simple one-pot reaction methodology. Fig. 1 illustrates the XRD patterns of the synthesized Zn,Co-ZIFs. It is clearly seen that the XRD patterns are identical for all Zn,Co-ZIFs samples. Diffraction peaks that appeared at 2θ values of 7.3, 10.4, 12.7, 14.8, 16.4 and 18.0 were identified for the (011), (002), (112), (002), (013) and (222) planes, respectively, of ZIF-8/ZIF-67 [45–47]. This result is not surprising, because ZIF-8(Zn) and ZIF-67(Co) have the same sodalite structure (SOD) and only small differences in lattice constant. FTIR spectral investigations also point towards the formation of ZIF-8, ZIF-67 and mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs (Figs. 2 and S1 (SI)). The band observed at 419 cm–1 (ν(Zn-N) stretching mode) in the spectrum of ZIF-8(Zn) indicates the formation of a bond between Zn2+ and the nitrogen atom of the linker. This band shifts to a higher wavenumber with insertion of Co2+ ions due to the substitution of Zn2+ ions. Similar to MAFs, this shift is related to the difference in electronegativity of Co2+ and Zn2+ that favors the formation of a more ionized bond in the case of ZIF-67(Co). Note that similar a blue shift also was demonstrated in the investigation of the nucleation and growth of ZIF-67(Co) and ZIF-8(Zn) thin films [48]. The spectrum of ZIF-8(Zn) showed bands at 760 cm–1 (ring out-of-plane bending), 1180 and 1150 cm–1 (ring in-plane bending vibration of imidazole), 1380 cm–1 (−CH3 symmetry deformation vibration), as well as bands in the region of 1340–1540 cm–1 corresponding to CN and CN, and the band at 1585 cm–1 attributed to an axial deformation is visible in the CN (Figs. 2 and S1 (SI)) [48]. In contrast to Zn-N stretching mode, these bands shift to a lower wavenumber with increasing number of Co2+ ions into framework of ZIF-8 (Fig. 2). According to DFT calculation [49], the M-N bond lengths are 1.98 and 1.96 Å for ZIF-8(Zn) and ZIF-67(Co), respectively (Fig. 2). The substitution of Zn2+ by Co2+ leads to the increasing C1-N-M and C2-N-M bond angles from 127.0 to 128.3 and from 128.8 to 129.6°, respectively (Fig. 2). At the same time, NC2-C3 bond angle decreases from 123.2 to 122.2°. Undoubtedly, these changes affect the interaction between -CH3 group and Co-/Zn- metal ions. DR-UV-vis spectra of ZIF-8, ZIF-67 and mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs are shown in Fig. 3 A. In spectrum of ZIF-8, we can reveal band at 225 nm attributed to π → π* transitions in the imidazole rings and a weak broad band in the region of 240–350 nm assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) band [46,50]. Insertion of Co2+ to the framework of ZIF-8 leads to the appearance of the bands in the regions of 240–350 and 400–700 nm, which are assigned to LMCT and the typical [4A2(F)-4T1(P)] d–d ligand field transitions in the tetrahedral cobalt ion (Fig. 3A) [51,52]. The intensities of these bands rise with increasing Co content in the mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs. Both Zn2+ ion and Co2+ bounds to the four ligands via nitrogen atoms in the structure of ZIFs (ZnIV and CoIV). According to DFT calculations [53,54], ZIF-8 can have low-coordinated Zn2+ (Zn2+ ions without one or two linkers, ZnIII and ZnII). Previously [13], we demonstrated that DR-UV-vis spectrum of MAF-6, formed between Zn2+ and 2-ethylimidazole, had bands at 300 and 360 nm that were assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer from low-coordinated Zn2+ (ZnIII and ZnII) to ligand and high-coordinated Zn2+ (ZnIV) to ligand, respectively. Therefore, we also can suggest that the bands at 252 and 295 nm are attributed to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer from low-coordinated Co2+ (CoIII and CoII) to ligand and high-coordinated Co2+ atoms (CoIV) to ligand, respectively. The ratio of band's intensities I252/I295 rises with increasing the Co content in the framework of mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs (Fig. 3B), i.e. the content of Co-formed active sites (CoIII and CoII) rises with increasing Co content in structure of Zn,Co-ZIFs. Textural properties of mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs also depend on the Co content in the structure (Table 3). In general, the increased Co content leads to the rising in the specific surface area and contribution of micropore volume to total pore volume (Vμ/VΣ). Thus, after the substitution of 25% of Zn2+ ions with Co2+ ions, specific surface area and Vμ/VΣ increase from 1938 to 1965 m2/g and from 0.90 to 0.95, respectively. Specific surface area (2058 m2/g) and (Vμ/VΣ) (1.0) of ZIF-67(Co) are higher in comparison with ZIF-8(Zn) that is likely explained by the slight difference in framework, namely the cavities with size of 11.6 Å accessible by small windows of 3.4 Å for ZIF-8(Zn) and the cavities of 11.4 Å and small windows of 3.3 Å for ZIF-67(Co) [55]. Synthesis and characterization of MAF-5 and MAF-6 materials. The MAF-5 and MAF-6 samples based on Zn2+ and Co2+ were synthesized by the solvothermal method for the understanding of the influence of the chemical composition on their catalytic properties. MAF-5 and MAF-6 samples have a high crystallinity that was confirmed by physicochemical investigations. For example, diffraction peaks observed in XRD patterns for MAF-6(Zn, Co) and MAF-5(Zn, Co) samples are consistent with XRD patterns of RHO structure [56] and ANA structure [57], respectively (Fig. 4 ). The high crystallinity of the materials is suggested by the reflexes (112) and (211) for MAF-5 and MAF-6, respectively, in the XRD diffractograms of the samples. The average size of the coherent scattering regions using the Debye-Scherrer's equation (SI) and textural properties of the samples are shown in Table 5. FTIR spectra of MAF-5 and MAF-6 samples are shown in Fig. 5 . The characteristic vibrations are highlighted as observed for both MAF-5(Zn,Co) and MAF-6(Zn,Co). There are Zn-N/Co-N stretching (ν(M-N), 420–430 cm–1 [58,59]), ring out-of-plane bending (700–800 cm–1 [58,59]), ring in-plane bending (1000–1200 cm–1 [58,59]), ring stretching modes (1350–1500 cm–1 [58,59]). A detailed look into the Co-N and Zn-N stretching region of Co-MAF and Zn-MAF IR spectra shows a blue shift for Co-based samples (426 and 427 cm–1 for MAF-5(Co) and MAF-6(Co), respectively) relative to Zn-based samples (423 and 417 cm–1 for MAF-5(Co) and MAF-6(Co), respectively). This phenomenon can be explained by the more electronegative nature of Co2+ (Pauling electronegativity 1.88) compared to Zn2+ (Pauling electronegativity 1.65) that leads to the formation of a more ionized bond, i.e., the formation of more tight bonds with M−N stretching vibrations at higher wavenumber. Note that a red shift is observed for the ring out-of-plane and in-plane bending modes (Fig. 5). We can assume that such behavior is because of the different interaction between –CH2CH3 groups and Co-/Zn- metal ions. 3.2 Catalytic properties of ZIFs Catalytic properties of Zn- and Co-containing ZIFs were investigated in the cycloaddition of CO2 to the PO in the presence of [n-Bu4N]Br as co-catalyst at 80 °C under 0.8 MPa of CO2. The main results are shown in Table 6 . According to the experimental data, the conversion of PO was less than 1% after 5 h in an experiment without any catalyst (Table 6, run 1). In the presence of 50 mg of [n-Bu4N]Br, conversion of PO was about 5% (Table 6, run 2), while in the presence of 50 mg of ZIFs, namely MAF-5(Zn) and MAF-6(Zn), the conversion of PO was 8.3 and 22.3%, respectively (Table 6, runs 3 and 6). At the same time, ZIFs/[n-Bu4N]Br binary system conversion of PO and yield of PC strongly increased. In all cases, PC was the major product with 99% selectivity. Note that catalytic properties of Zn- and Co-containing ZIFs were investigated in optimal conditions, when weight ratio of ZIF/[n-Bu4N]Br was 1/1 (Fig. S7, SI). Activities of Zn-containing binary systems (Table 6, runs 4, 9 and 9) were higher in comparison with those of the Co-containing binary systems (Table 6, runs 5, 8 and 14). To explain the main reasons for the difference in the catalytic properties of ZIF-8(Zn) and ZIF-67(Co), the reaction mechanism should be considered. As presented in Scheme S1 (SI), the active center might be suggested as a pair "Lewis acid site - basic site" (LAS-BS). The activation of PO proceeds on the Lewis acid site, while the Lewis basic site activates a CO2 molecule [60,61]. The addition of [n-Bu4N]Br to catalyst accelerates the ring-opening step due to the nucleophilic attack to C1 atom of epoxide and producing an intermediate. Therefore, the lower activity of ZIF-67(Co) than ZIF-8(Zn) can be related to the difference in the accessibility of active sites to reagents. According to Krokidas et al. [49,55], these materials have slight differences in the frameworks (Fig. 2). ZIF-8(Zn) possesses larger cavity (11.6 Å) and pore aperture (3.4 Å) sizes than those for ZIF-67(Co) (11.4 Å and 3.3 Å, respectively) [55]. Moreover, ZIF-8(Zn) and ZIF-67(Co) differ in textural properties (Table 5). The contribution of micropore volume to total pore volume (Vμ/VΣ) is higher for ZIF-67(Co) in comparison with that in ZIF-8(Zn). All these differences can affect adsorption and diffusion of reagents. The different number of active sites and strength of the interaction between Co-formed active sites and reagents can be the other reason of the low activity of Co-containing ZIFs. Correlation between the yield of the PC and the number of Co-formed Lewis acidic sites (I252/I295) is shown in Fig. 3B. One can be seen from this correlation, the yield of the PC decreases with increasing the number of active sites formed by low-coordinated Co2+ (CoIII and CoII). This phenomenon can be explained by several reasons. Firstly, according to investigations of CO2 uptake of metal-substituted MOFs (M-DOBDC, M-HKUST-1, M-CPO-27, and M-MOF-74, M: Co and Zn) [62–64], zinc has higher binding strength with CO2 than Co due to the higher effective charge on compared to that on cobalt. Meshkat et al. [65] demonstrated that this difference led to the higher CO2 solubility coefficient of ZIF-8(Zn) in comparison with that of ZIF-67(Co). Qi et al. [66] investigated catalytic properties of nitrogen-doped porous carbon material (Zn/CN, Co/CN and Co,Zn/CN (Co/Zn - 1:1) synthesized via thermal pyrolysis of zeolitic imidazole frameworks (Co,Zn-ZIFs) in cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. It was demonstrated that efficiency (conversion and selectivity) of Zn/CN (85 and 84%, respectively) was higher in comparison with Co,Zn/CN (12 and 11%) and Co/CN (12 and 7%) in cycloaddition of CO2 to epichlorohydrin. This phenomenon was explained by the data of CO2-TPD analysis. It was found that a significant part of the adsorbed CO2 is desorbed at a lower temperature (510 °C) from Zn/CN compared to Zn,Co/CN (684 °C).The smallest amount of desorption was observed for Co/CN. We can assume that a degree of CO2 uptake decreases with increasing Co2+ content into the framework of mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs; and, thereby change the reaction rate (Fig. 3B). Probably, similar behavior could be also observed in the interaction of PO with active sites. An increased affinity of the PO in the Zn-formed active sites may be the reason of higher conversion of PO in the presence of ZIF-8(Zn) in comparison with ZIF-67(Co) (Table 6, runs 9 and 14). Other explanation of the change in catalytic properties with increasing Co content in Co,Zn-ZIF can be related with the decreasing NC2-C3 (from 123.2 to 122.2°) and C1-N-C2 (from 105.0 to 104.0°) bond angles with increasing Co content into framework of Zn,Co-ZIFs (Fig. 2) [49]. This change can affect the accessibility of active sites for reagents (Fig. 3B). We also compared the efficiency of Co- and Zn-formed MAF-5 and MAF-6 in the cycloaddition. As shown in Table 5 (runs 4, 5 and 7, 8), the activity of Co-containing materials is lower than that of Zn-containing materials. Based on the above, it can be argued that this difference also relates to the accessibility of active centers to reagents and the strength of the interaction with CO2 and propylene oxide. Another important point was to investigate the effect of structure on the activity of ZIFs. The correlation between pore aperture of ZIFs and conversion of the PO is shown in Fig. 6 . It is clearly seen that the conversion of PO rises with increasing the size of pore aperture both for Zn- and Co-containing ZIFs. A similar trend is observed for the reaction between CO2 and styrene oxide. In contrast to reaction of PC, the cycloaddition of CO2 to styrene oxide was investigated without the addition of co-catalyst at 50 °C under 1.2 MPa of CO2 for 24 h. Effect of pore aperture on the activity of ZIFs can be explained by the change in the accessibility of active sites and diffusion limitations. The larger pore aperture, the larger accessibility of active sites and lower diffusion limitation. Therefore, the highest activity of MAF-6 in comparison with other ZIFs is due to the large aperture of MAF-6(Zn) (about 7.6 Å) among the studied catalysts [67] (Table 1). 4 Summary The present study demonstrated the successful use of a Zn-, Co- and Zn,Co-mixed zeolitic-imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) as catalysts for the synthesis of propylene carbonate from propylene oxide and CO2. The main attention was focused on a study on the textural, physicochemical and catalytic properties of the isostructural ZIFs, such as ZIF-8(Zn)/ZIF-67(Co), MAF-5(Zn)/MAF-5(Co) and MAF-6(Zn)/MAF-6(Co). The studied ZIFs were characterized by XRD, BET, FTIR techniques. It was found that textural properties of mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs depend on the Co content in structure of solid. Thus, the insertion of Co2+ ions into the framework of ZIF-8(Zn) leads to the increasing the specific surface area and the contribution of micropore volume to total pore volume (Vμ/VΣ). The higher specific surface area and (Vμ/VΣ) of ZIF-67(Co) in comparison with ZIF-8(Zn) can be explained by the slight difference in framework, namely cavities with size of 11.6 Å accessible by small windows of 3.4 Å for ZIF-8(Zn) and cavities of 11.4 Å and small windows of 3.3 Å for ZIF-67(Co). Investigation of Zn,Co-ZIFs by DR-UV-vis spectroscopy supports the presence of low-coordinated Co2+ (CoIII and CoII) (band at 252 nm) and high-coordinated Co2+ ions (CoIV) (band at 295 nm). The ratio of band's intensities I252/I295 rises with increasing Co content in the framework of mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs. Similar trends were observed for MAF-5(Zn)/MAF-5(Co) and MAF-6(Zn)/MAF-6(Co) materials. Catalytic properties of Zn- and Co-containing ZIFs were investigated in the cycloaddition of CO2 to PO at 80 °C under 0.8 MPa of CO2. In all cases, PC was the major product with 99% selectivity. The addition of [n-Bu4N]Br to ZIFs as co-catalyst increased the reaction rate. The catalytic properties of Zn- and Co-containing ZIFs were compared in optimal conditions, when the weight ratio of ZIF/[n-Bu4N]Br was 1/1. The activity of Zn-containing materials was higher in comparison with Co-formed materials. The activity of mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs was dependent on the Co content in a structure. The activity of Zn,Co-ZIFs decreased with increasing Co content that was related to the accessibility of active centers to reagents and the strength of their interaction with CO2 and propylene oxide. The increasing the strength of basic sites reduced to the decreasing activity of Zn-ZIFs due to the increasing strength of interaction between basic sites and CO2; therefore, the slower removal of products from the active sites. At the same time, the activity of Zn-ZIFs rose with increasing the size of pore aperture that was ascribed to the decreasing diffusion limitations. In general, based on the results of the present work, the Zn-ZIFs could be considered as the promising catalysts for cyclocondensation of CO2 with epoxides and thereby opens new paths for further research. coredata.dc:description: A series of Zn- and Co containing zeolitic-imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), such as ZIF-8(Zn)/ZIF-67(Co), MAF-5(Zn)/MAF-5(Co), and MAF-6(Zn)/MAF-6(Co), were investigated as catalysts for the synthesis of propylene carbonate (PC) from propylene oxide (PO) and CO2. The effect of the chemical composition, textural, structural and physicochemical properties on their activity was investigated. It was found that the activity of Zn-containing materials was higher in comparison with Co-based materials. Moreover, the yield of a PC was decreased with increasing Co content in structure of mixed Zn,Co-ZIFs (ZIF-8/ZIF-67) that was related to the accessibility of active centers to reagents and the strength of their interaction with CO2 and propylene oxide. The catalytic performance of Zn-ZIFs was found to improve with increasing the size of pore aperture due to the guest molecule facile diffusion and accessibility of the active site for reagent. In general, based on the results of the present work, the Zn-ZIFs could be considered as promising catalysts for cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides and thereby opens new paths for further research.
coredata.dc:title: Tuning the catalytic properties for cycloaddition of CO2 to propylene oxide on zeolitic-imidazolate frameworks through variation of structure and chemical composition
